t: Isaiah 33
The Lord Rises Up
Woe,*pn you destroyer never destroyed, you*ln traitor never betrayed! When*ln you have finished destroying, you*ln will be destroyed. When*ln you have finished betraying, they*ln will betray you.
Lord,*sln be gracious to us! We wait for you. Be*ln our strength every morning and*ln our salvation in time of trouble.
The*ln peoples flee at the thunderous noise; the*ln nations scatter when you rise in your majesty.
Your*ln spoil will be gathered as locusts are gathered; people*ln will swarm over it like an infestation of locusts.
The*ln Lord*s is exalted, for he dwells on high; he*ln has filled Zion with justice and righteousness.
There*ln will be times of security for you — a*ln storehouse of salvation, wisdom, and knowledge. The*ln fear of the Lord*s is Zion’s treasure.
Listen!*ln Their warriors cry loudly in the streets; the*ln messengers of peace weep bitterly.
The*pn highways are deserted; travel*ln has ceased. An*ln agreement has been broken, cities*ln despised, and*ln human life disregarded.
The*ln land mourns and withers; Lebanon*ln is ashamed and wilted. Sharon*ln is like a desert; Bashan*ln and Carmel shake off their leaves.
“Now*ln I will rise up,” says the Lord.*s “Now*ln I will lift myself up. Now*ln I will be exalted.
You*ln will conceive chaff; you*ln will give birth to stubble. Your*ln breath is fire that will consume you.
The*ln peoples will be burned to ashes, like*ln thorns cut down and burned in a fire.
You*ln who are far off, hear what I have done; you*ln who are near, know my strength.”
The*ln sinners in Zion are afraid; trembling*ln seizes the ungodly: “Who*ln among us can dwell with a consuming fire? Who*ln among us can dwell with ever-burning flames?”

The*ln one who lives righteously and*ln speaks rightly, who*ln refuses profit from extortion, whose*ln hand never takes a bribe, who*ln stops his ears from listening to murderous plots and*ln shuts his eyes against evil schemes—
he*ln will dwell on the heights; his*ln refuge will be the rocky fortresses, his*ln food provided, his water assured.
Your*ln eyes will see the King in his beauty; you*ln will see a vast land.
Your*ln mind will meditate on the past terror: “Where*ln is the accountant? Where*ln is the tribute collector? Where*ln is the one who spied out our defenses?”
You*ln will no longer see the barbarians, a*ln people whose speech is difficult to comprehend — who*ln stammer in a language that is not understood.

Look*ln at Zion, the city of our festival times. Your*ln eyes will see Jerusalem, a*ln peaceful pasture, a tent that does not wander; its*ln tent pegs will not be pulled up nor*ln will any of its cords be loosened.
For*ln the majestic one, our Lord,*s will be there, a*ln place of rivers and broad streams where*ln ships that are rowed will not go, and*ln majestic vessels will not pass.
For*ln the Lord*s is our Judge, the*ln Lord*s is our Lawgiver, the*ln Lord*s is our King. He*ln will save us.
Your*ln ropes are slack; they*ln cannot hold the base of the mast or*ln spread out the flag. Then*ln abundant spoil will be divided, the*ln lame will plunder it,
and*ln none there will say, “I am sick.” The*ln people who dwell there will*ln be forgiven their iniquity.
